texts.shortText:
Worm shells are an unusual group in that the whorls of the shell have become largely uncoiled and irregular and are attached permanently to the substratum (or one another) by one side. They are often mistaken for tube-dwelling polychaetes.

This species is relatively small and gregarious, forming large, flat, intertwining masses or ‘reefs’ of tubes on the upper surfaces of rocks in the low intertidal. The off-white tubes themselves are often covered by coralline algae, leaving only the apertures visible, each of which is closed by a dark red-brown horny operculum.
Individuals only about 10 mm in length, but colonies may be 30 cm or more across.

Global: Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to about Hermanus.

Very common in the low intertidal, where it forms extensive flat reefs coating the upper surfaces of rocks in areas of strong water flow. Often overgrown with encrusting algae, so that the intertwining white tubes are concealed and only the openings are visible, each closed by a dark, reddish-brown, horny operculum, often with a yellow centre. The intertwined structure and transverse growth ridges of the bluish-white shells is in fact best seen on eroded pieces of colony that have been washed ashore!
Filter-feeder, forming a net of mucous strands that are used to capture floating food particles. After some time the net is gathered in by the radula and the captured food items consumed.

Broods up to 11 egg-capsules in a single row within the mantle cavity, each capsule containing a single embryo. The free-swimming larvae can settle within 24 h, but can also delay metamorphosis for 4–5 days if suitable substrata are not found. The larvae prefer to settle on encrusting coralline algae and use the radula to dig a groove, into which they can firmly attach themselves. Young are released from July-December.

Replaced from the Eastern Cape northwards by the almost identical D. tholia. The Solitary worm-shell Thylacodes natalensis occurs in the same region, but is much larger, pinky-white in colour, is solitary and lacks an operculum.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 182).

Hughes, RN (2008). The biology of Dendropoma corallinaceum and Serpulorbis natalensis, two South African vermetid gastropods. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 64(2), 111–127.

Kilburn, R & Rippey, E (1982). Sea Shells of Southern Africa. Macmillan South Africa, Johannesburg (p. 52)
